unnormalised: Many of India's major festivals are tied to the Hindu lunar calendar, meaning their Gregorian calendar dates shift annually. Diwali, the festival of lights, typically falls between mid-October and mid-November (e.g., 12/11/2023). Holi, the festival of colors, usually occurs in March (e.g., 25/03/2024). The exact timing is determined by astrological calculations and the position of the moon. Some festivals like Raksha Bandhan, a celebration of the bond between siblings, also depend on the full moon day of Shravan month, which usually falls in Aug (e.g., 22/08/2024).

unnormalised: Regional variations add another layer of complexity. Pongal, a harvest festival primarily celebrated in Tamil Nadu, takes place around 14/01 each year, coinciding with Makar Sankranti, celebrated in other parts of India. Durga Puja, a major festival in West Bengal, typically spans five days in September or October (e.g., from 18/10/2023 to 22/10/2023). The specific dates are based on the lunar calendar and vary slightly each year.
